intro: Hippocrepis comosa subsp. macedonica, commonly known as the Macedonian thimbleweed, is a flowering plant native to the Balkan Peninsula. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, characterized by its small, cruciform flowers and segmented fruits. The subspecies is distinguished by its hairy, glandular leaves and pale yellow to white flowers that bloom in late spring. It typically grows in rocky or limestone soils in open habitats such as grasslands and forest edges. This plant is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and limited distribution.
